nytimes_articles.abstract: Quorums by Proxy Question: Since a quorum always refers to the number of members present and not to the number voting, is it legal under New York State Business Corporation Law to establish a quorum by adding proxies to present members? . . . Theodore R. Smith, the Bronx

nytimes_articles.headline: A Trove of Greene and Greene Houses
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT the turn of the century, Midwesterners came to Pasadena to winter in a semi-arid landscape offering dependable sun and panoramas of the majestic San Gabriel Mountain range and its expansive valley. The houses they built in these rolling foothills and along the boulder-strewn, oak-rich ravine that cleaves the city -- the Arroyo Seco -- record the values of what has been called the Arroyo Culture.   These new arrivals were the liberal Democrats who supported national parks, women's suffrage, progressive education, healthful living and a Craftsman ethic and esthetic -- the Americans who were looking to the land itself to forge an American cultural identity independent of Europe's. Home-grown architecture was very much an instrument of this idealism, and the unpretentious wood-frame villas they built in Pasadena, fused with its noble landscape, embodied the apparently simple life and democratic values they espoused.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Demothballing Developments Along I-78
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE mid-80's building boom inspired a spate of corporations to set up headquarters along the western stretch of Interstate 78, which slices through the rolling hills of Hunterdon County. But the recession stanched the wave of speculative development that was expected to follow.

In the last decade, said John W. Kellogg, the county planning director, the construction of four million square feet of offices was approved along a 20-mile section of the interstate. Of that, 1.4 million was built, most of it for owner-users.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
40 Flutes, Some Humor and a Bit of Fire
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ABOUT three years ago, Trevor Wye, a British flutist, retired from his teaching position and decided it was time to tell the public the history of the flute, how it works and what kinds of flutes exist. 

Beginning with a few flutes that he used for a children's program, Mr. Wye, a collector of rare and unusual flutes, gradually developed a program he called "Afflatus." In it, he uses 40 different types of flutes, which he plays one after another, including the rare "triple flageolet" and a flute that catches fire, and speaks about the instruments and the music.

nytimes_articles.headline: Balkan Peace Talks Resume as War Drags On
nytimes_articles.abstract: Overshadowed by a renewed offensive in western Croatia and by battles in Bosnia and Herzegovina, talks on ending the Balkan war resumed here today among top leaders of all hostile factions.   Shortly after noon, the leaders of the Serbs, Croats and the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia renewed pledges to accept the principles of a peace settlement drafted by a special United Nations mediator, Cyrus R. Vance, and the European Community envoy, Lord Owen. The proposal would create a reconstituted republic with 10 ethnically mixed provinces that would be largely self-governing.

nytimes_articles.headline:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Quebec
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In a 1964 song that the Quebecois took to heart like no other, the chansonnier Gilles Vigneault sang, "My country isn't a country, it's winter." If that sounds like a lament, you don't know Quebec, where long ago they decided to make their frosty fate one more excuse for communal merrymaking. In Quebec City, where January and February can be punishingly cold, that translates into Carnival. 

In the 19th century, winter carnivals appeared and disappeared in that city with a certain Gallic spontaneity. The sporty 1880 festival featured snowshoe races on the Plains of Abraham, horse races on the frozen St. Charles River and canoe races on the partially frozen St. Lawrence. By 1894, when Quebec City was a 20-hour train ride from New York and rooms at the Chateau Frontenac cost about $4, the carnival was recognizably modern.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jean Harris's Plans Include Helping Inmates
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jean S. Harris yesterday spent her first full day of freedom in nearly 12 years recuperating from coronary bypass surgery and preparing to commit herself to helping the children of the imprisoned women she left behind, her lawyer said.   Mrs. Harris, who was convicted in 1981 of murdering her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower, is staying with friends, following her release Friday night from the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. Her lawyer, Leon Friedman, declined to disclose the location of her current residence, but state officials said last week that she would remain in Westchester County for a few months.

nytimes_articles.headline: Julie E. Farris, Kevin Valentine
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. David J. Farris of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Julie Ellen Farris and Kevin John Valentine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Valentine of Landing, N.J.   Miss Farris, 28, is a kindergarten teacher at the Bedwell Elementary School in Bernardsville. She graduated from Lebanon Valley College and received a master's degree in education from Seton Hall University. Her father is chief operating officer of the Beneficial Corporation of Wilmington, Del., a consumer-finance company, and heads the company's management subsidiary in Peapack, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Dropping In for Ouzo and Appetizers in Athens
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TAVERNAS get all the press, but the ouzeri may well be the definitive dining experience in Athens. These bars-cum-eateries, the Greek answer to the tapas bar, offer a window on the city's social life and cuisine.

Casual and affordable, ouzeris are 

the 

place to dish with friends and family over a spread of Greek appetizers, known as mezedes. And unlike Spaniards who nibble on tapas as a prelude to dinner, Athenians are content to make a meal of starters such as tiny fried peppers and moussaka or more nouvelle preparations like brains in black butter and a salad of sauteed mushrooms, raw zucchini and dill.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article last Sunday about a new process for converting natural gas to methanol misidentified a chemical. From 1992 to 1994 the United States is expected to triple its capacity to make methyl tertiary butyl ether, which is derived from methanol, not to triple the capacity to make methanol itself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patch by Patch, Putting Life Together
nytimes_articles.abstract:
CREATING quilts was a way for women to speak out -- on politics, during celebrations, in good times and in bad. Quilting represented a coming together to create an object of warmth, but the art was also an avenue in which to apply the hands, head and heart to a craft.

For "Textile Diaries: Quilts as Cultural Markers," an exhibition on view at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center through Feb. 21, antique and contemporary quilts were selected from the Kansas Quilt Project -- a statewide undertaking that registered more than 13,000 quilts between 1986 and 1988. The display perceives quilts as personal diaries that record the experiences of the quilter and the recipient.
Inspired by Kansas

 The project's goals, inspired in part by the 125th anniversary of Kansas statehood, were several: to heighten awareness of quilts as examples of Kansas folk art, to document the lives of the quilters and their work, to collect data on quilting and to establish a repository at the Kansas State Historical Society with the hope of promoting the art of quilting.

"Quilt Discovery Days," held on weekends throughout Kansas during a 16-month period, encouraged the public to bring in quilts and share their stories. Those that were very old and fresh from the quilting frame were solicited, as were those made in Kansas. The project's second phase sought groups and individuals who would not normally share their quilts at public functions, like museums and quilting clubs.

"For the women who made these quilts, and it was primarily a woman's craft, they were creating something useful, but it was also a way of expressing feelings, political happenings, grief, joy and hopes," said the museum's director of education and curator of the Stamford exhibition, Kai Underwood.

"Probably one of the most significant differences between quilters then and now is that they used to gather together to produce their craft work. It was an important social outlet and community activity.
For Walls not Beds

 "Today while there is a revival of women grouping together, some individuals create quilts as an artist, like a painter. And the quilt is seen less as a bed coverlet than as an object of art to hang on walls."

The display captures the pride of quilters past plying traditional patterns in kaleidoscopic ways, and in bold contrast, the best of contemporary, painterly innovations.

Divided into three themed sections -- "Rites of Passage," "Personal Memories" and "Marking Community Events" -- 18 quilts are showcased, accompanied by texts and photographs telling the stories of the quilters. Most, though not all, are patchwork quilts. "Making a quilt out of small patches, pieces of remnant cloth, is an American invention amply brought out in this exhibit," Mr. Underwood said "People were land-rich and cash-poor. They saved worn-out clothing as well as other scraps so they could piece them together to create a larger coverlet."

Women made quilts for themselves and as gifts to mark significant events. They recorded rites of passage: birth, graduation, marriage and death. Patterns were not symbolic of the occasion but simply represented their favorite.

Quilts for babies in the 1800's were most often full size, represented in the exhibition by a "Mexican Rose" pattern, appliqued with vibrant red and orange flowers by a mother expecting her sixth child in Sandusky, Ohio. The quilt was brought to Kansas by her son 60 years later.

During the Victorian era, attitudes toward children changed. They were treated distinctly with juvenile theme patterns, illustrated in the show with a very feminine child-size, scalloped-edge animal applique quilt.
Any Pattern Will Do

 There were no hard and fast rules to selecting patterns. "Double Wedding Ring," a favorite used for graduation as well as marriage, is shown in blocks of brilliant pastels, constructed like an intricate patchwork jigsaw puzzle.

A mourning quilt, "Grandmother's Flower Garden," uses small patterned flowery colors plucked from the dresses of a daughter who died at the tender age of 8.

In "Princess Feather," a mother playfully quilted corners with outlines of her own, daughter's and infant son's hands and feet. A friendship quilt, often a gift for those moving to the West, features blocks embroidered with the signatures of family friends, statements and the names of garments they came from.

One of the more contemporary quilts, "Oh Beautiful," was chosen as the Kansas entry to a national contest during the centennial of the Statue of Liberty. Against an undulating landscape of fields, mountains and ocean, the statue's torch is flung high and a three-dimensional flag draped across the torso.

"You have to ask yourself whether the maker ever intended to see it on a bed or created it purely as an art form," Mr. Underwood said..
Monday Quilting Bees

 A 30-minute video, "Quilts in Women's Lives" portrays seven contemporary quilters. And a quilting bee demonstration, conducted by the museum's quilting group, takes place every Monday from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.

"The show reinforces the important role quilting played among women as an avenue of expression, not only of feelings but of skills," Mr. Underwood said. "It was one of the few ways they could demonstrate their expertise in a creative way."



Stamford Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road, is open Monday through Saturday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.

At 5:30 A.M. the captain directed passengers to put on life jackets and report to their lifeboat stations. He then announced that there was a fire in the engine room, which was under control. nytimes_articles.headline: Hangin' With the Nintendo Generation
nytimes_articles.abstract: For more than a year, "hard-core" has been the most vibrant dance-music cult in Britain.  The term comes from "hard-core techno," a brutal, high-speed style of electronic rave music. Early on, hard-core meant bombastic synthesizer -- programmed machine-rhythms and a clinical though crazed atmosphere. But the music evolved into a hybrid of hip-hop and techno, merging the former's grit with the latter's futuristic weirdness, as disk jockeys and producers started to take beats from rap records and speed them up. In the process, they retained hip-hop's funky syncopation, yet at tempos (140 to 150 beats per minute) far faster than any flesh-and-blood drummer could sustain.   Combining the revelry of disco and the disorientation of psychedelia, rave music tends to be brazenly druggy, in both its sound and its lyrical allusions. Hard-core is no exception. Its manic pace has been influenced by the fact that ecstasy, the raver's stimulant of choice, has become steadily more adulterated with amphetamine.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Smorgasbord for the Ears
nytimes_articles.abstract: When David McLees, a projects supervisor for Rhino Records, wanted to use the song "Max's Kansas City" on the label's nine-volume compilation of punk and new wave, he followed the money trail. Since songwriters, like everyone else, expect to be paid for their work, he figured that someone connected with Wayne County, the obscure New York band that produced the song, would be registered with ASCAP or BMI. Wrong. Next he turned to the American Federation of Musicians. Strike two.   Mr. McLees then took the investigative avenue of last resort: telephone information. He got lucky. There was a listing in Brooklyn under the name of the group's bass player, Gene Geary. But the number was for the punk rocker's father, who said his son lived a few blocks away -- without a phone. The father got word to the son, and, eventually, the song ended up on the compilation, "D.I.Y.," named for the "do-it-yourself" ethic of early punk bands.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plan the Kitchen and Avoid Pitfalls
nytimes_articles.abstract: READY-TO-ASSEMBLE kitchen cabinets make remodeling a kitchen much easier than when cabinets were just available ready-made or built to order by a cabinetmaker. But planning the sizes, and determining how the cabinets will look when installed, can still be challenging, unless the new cabinets will be exactly the same sizes as the old ones.   Many stores selling cabinets have computerized-design services. They are often free and can produce views of how the kitchen would look when completed and figure dimensions and prices. But making scale drawings on graph paper is also a reliable and easy way to plan, one that allows making comparisons between cabinet models carried by different stores and frees you from dealing with salespeople until you have clear ideas of what you want.

nytimes_articles.headline: Their Songs Were America's Happy Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Once upon a time, America dreamed of itself as a singing fairy tale for grown-ups, with a happy ending. Norman Rockwell painted this storybook country, and Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d wrote its songs. More than just pop confections, they added up to a kind of secular catechism that sweetly but firmly instructed people on the rules of behavior in a world where America knew best and good triumphed over evil.   Certainly, Rodgers and Hammerstein didn't invent the code of values that their songs taught. With their stern, semioperatic melodies and know-it-all lyrics, they offered an idealized mirror image of American middle-class morality in the heady afterglow of Hitler's defeat. At a moment when everyone understood what was meant by terms like "maturity," "good citizenship" and "mental hygiene," they helped define the notion of a national culture.

nytimes_articles.headline: Live, and in Sizzling Color, The Trashing of the Island

The question is, Is Long Island becoming a laughingstock to the rest of the nation?   Consider other recent Long Island news that has been on the network newscasts. First there was the Islip garbage barge, all loaded up with no place to go. Then there was Jessica Hahn, a church secretary in Massapequa who said she had a one-day stand in a Florida motel with the television evangelist Jim Bakker and was paid $265,000 in hush money. Last year there was John McNamara, the automobile dealer from Port Jefferson who admitted bilking General Motors of $6 billion. Then there was New York State's top judge, Sol Wachtler of Manhasset, who was arrested on the Long Island Expressway and charged with threatening a woman with whom he reportedly had had a romantic relationship. nytimes_articles.headline: 'Passion Fish' Nourishes the Grown-Ups
nytimes_articles.abstract: John Sayles is one of those unfortunate film makers who is often damned with great praise. "Matewan," the tale of a 1920 West Virginia miners' strike, and "City of Hope," the story of racial tension and urban blight in a New Jersey town, were acclaimed for being rigorous, uncompromising social visions. That kind of praise can kill a picture, and pretty much did. Audiences saw code words for dreary, depressing, stay away.    In fact, both films are exhilarating in a gritty, hard-to-sell way. They carry viewers to unglamorous places where people are as worried and messed up as your next-door neighbors, though a lot more interesting about it. nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton and Yeltsin Aides to Arrange Summit
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin spoke by telephone today and agreed to arrange a summit.   The White House Press Secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin had agreed that Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, would meet to work out the details.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pentagon Agrees to Delay a Reactor Test in Space
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pentagon officials, responding to complaints by astronomers, have agreed to defer for at least six months any commitments to carry out a nuclear reactor test in orbit. The delay would give scientists time to assess the chances that the test might produce radiation that could interfere with astronomical observations.   The decision was reached last week after a meeting with astronomers, mission planners and scientists familiar with the Russian-made Topaz 2 nuclear reactor planned for use in the $150 million experiment. The reactor test is part of the military's plan to investigate new technologies for generating electricity for missile defense monitors in space and for long-distance propulsion systems.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ROSE REASON
By Mary Flanagan.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $23.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democrats In Their Glory
nytimes_articles.abstract: Washington's inaugural balls welcomed over 70,000 on Jan. 20.

nytimes_articles.headline: A la Carte; The Charm of Cold Spring Harbor Is Limitless
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE quaint North Shore village of Cold Spring Harbor has a seaside style of its own, and the cozy new Cold Spring Harbor Cafe, at 134 Main Street (367-6060), has a colonial look that fits right in.    The inside of this casual sidewalk cafe is inviting as well, with its Tiffany lamps, stained-glass skylight, impressive copper espresso machine and front-room dessert display.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Summer School Program for Teachers
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT may be some students' idea of the ultimate revenge: summer school for teachers. But Westchester students will be the final beneficiaries of a new program planned by the State University of New York here to establish an intensive teacher-training program on its campus this July.   The goal of the program, called Purchase Teachers' Academy, is to inform teachers about developments in the subjects they teach and give them the skills necessary to implement their new knowledge. The result should be better-quality teaching in local schools.

nytimes_articles.headline: Delegation Gains Posts To Guard Home Front
nytimes_articles.abstract: NO one knows exactly what it takes to win a coveted seat on a major Congressional committee because voting on assignments takes place behind closed doors. The ingredients seem to be a predictable political mixture of seniority, networking, regional affiliation and power of personality.   Whatever the magical formula, the Connecticut delegation managed to work wonders in the waning days of 1992, coming out of December's assignment frenzy with appointments to four of the most prized committees. The assignments will add to the delegation's clout in the 103d Congress, influence already enhanced by its building seniority and enviable connections to the new White House.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Female Rabbi With Spirituality Enough to Make History
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT is a frigid Saturday morning in mid-January, but inside the intimate sanctuary of Congregation Genesis-Agudas Achim, Rabbi Susan Grossman is just beginning to warm to her subject -- talking to teen-age children about God. Leaving the elevated perch of her pulpit, she begins to stroll, a la Donahue, down the aisle of the synagogue, articulating her position, encouraging congregants to contribute their thoughts and queries on the subject.

Standing in a self-conscious group on the carpeted stage are a group of three adolescent girls that Rabbi Grossman has assembled for this morning's sermon. Planted in the audience, the rabbi asks the girls on the stage to share their perceptions of God. The sanctuary is soundless as the faces of the 50 congregants turn toward the tentative voices of the girls, listening, radiating pride.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Acting Should Be A Joy'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Stella Adler, who died late last month at the age of 91, broke the mold around the teaching of the Stanislavski system of acting. The myth of the Method in many areas had become rigid, encased in sacred do's and don'ts. She challenged them all, to make it a living, ever-changing approach to acting, rid of cliches and dogma.

nytimes_articles.headline: Focus: Oakland, Calif.; Collecting on Insurance After the '91 Fire
nytimes_articles.abstract: A FIRESTORM in October 1991 swept over the steep hills of this city and destroyed the home of Ron and Bette Bugaj, among 3,300 other houses here and in neighboring Berkeley. But as far as Mr. Bugaj is concerned, "the damage we really suffered was in our negotiations with our insurance company."   The Bugajes's home-insurance policy, for which they paid about $750 a year, stipulated that if there was a fire or other catastrophe the couple, both physical therapists, would have their 2,100-square-foot, four-bedroom home fully rebuilt and their belongings replaced.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Sky's the Limit, But Don't Bank on Elvis
nytimes_articles.abstract: FRESH from Elvis ecstasy, the United States Postal Service this week moves on to another hot topic for stamp designs, space exploration. Several surveys by the Linn's Stamp Weekly and American Topical Association, a national group of people who collect stamps by subject, have shown that space travel is the most popular topic among collectors.    Tomorrow, in Huntsville, Ala., the Postal Service is to issue a booklet of five 29-cent stamps that depict fantasy voyages in space. Of course, the post office cannot please all collectors all the time, and some space-stamp collectors are complaining about this issue. They say that only real events belong on topical stamps.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Motels Added to List of Shelters for Families
nytimes_articles.abstract: Confronted with families sleeping on table tops and dirty floors in city welfare offices, the Dinkins administration has announced plans to shelter more than 60 homeless families in two more motels, one in the Bronx and the other on Staten Island.   The two will join a list of 22 other hotels and motels throughout the city that are now housing about 1,100 homeless families.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elisabeth Murdoch, Elkin K. Pianim
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation media empire, and Anna Murdoch of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Murdoch, to Elkin Kwesi Pianim, a son of A. Kwame and Cornelia Pianim of Accra, Ghana. A September wedding is planned.    Ms. Murdoch, 24, is the program director of KSTU-TV in Salt Lake City, a Fox station owned and operated by the News Corporation, based in Sydney, Australia. Ms. Murdoch and her fiance graduated from Vassar College. Her father is the News Corporation's chairman and chief executive. Her mother is the author of three novels, including "Coming to Terms," published in 1991 by HarperCollins.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: Brighton Beach
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Russian influence in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn is so pervasive -- Pat Singer, executive director of the Brighton Beach Association, says emigres make up 60 percent of the population -- that it has been dubbed "Little Odessa by the Sea."   Ms. Singer dates the surge of immigration to 1979, when the Soviet Union began easing Jewish emigration and thus opened the gates to creating what is probably this country's largest Russian-emigre community.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds of Venice
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: In "The Serene Sounds of Venice," Louis Inturrisi remembers the sound of the locals talking -- "that energetic blend of lilting intonation and slushy sibilants."   For my part, I enjoy just watching a Venetian conversation out of earshot, the gesticulating. They paint air pictures of the spoken words that I've never seen watched by the listener.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Long Island Q&A;: Azad K. Anand;
65,000 M.R.I.'s a Year In Doctor's 5 Clinics
nytimes_articles.abstract:
DR. AZAD K. ANAND, who is 45, came to the United States from his native India in 1975 after briefly practicing medicine there. He is founder and president of Long Island Diagnostic Imaging, which has offices in Lake Success, Rego Park, Ridge, East Setauket and Syosset.

From 1976 through 1979, Dr. Anand had a fellowship in neuroradiology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He trained there and at the Memorial Hospital-Sloan Kettering Cancer Institute from 1979 through 1981.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; A Just January
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the sky isn't spitting rain it's spitting snow -- enough to be a nuisance, too little to make things pretty. After a few fitful appearances the sun disappears for good along about noon. Which is just about the time the wind is picking up speed. Waiting for the bus is even less fun than usual. Getting up in the morning is no joy either. Going to bed is a pleasure.   So celebrate! After several years during which August sometimes seemed like April, October like July and one winter (last winter, to be precise) like a peculiarly extended March, one month at least has finally gotten its act together.

nytimes_articles.headline: Supreme Court No Longer Protects Privacy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   William Safire suggests but does not mention in "Peeping Tom Lives" (column, Jan. 4) one of the main reasons so much personal information is now easily available to the Government. That reason is the Supreme Court, which has resolutely refused to adapt the Fourth Amendment to modern conditions of life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Insurers Second-Guess Doctors, Provoking Debate Over Savings
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Robert Sawyer, a Denver surgeon, has a full-time office manager to get approval from insurers to perform operations. He also speaks to the companies every couple of days himself to report on patients' progress, spending about an hour each day on the phone justifying his patients' care.   In the case of a patient whose extensive intestinal bleeding prompted a two-month hospital stay, he fielded daily calls from her insurance company requesting minute details: the volume of urine she had produced and the drip rate of her intravenous lines.

nytimes_articles.headline: Knicks Are Striving To Maintain Groove
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Knicks needed the kind of week they just finished.   They won three games. They restored whatever confidence they had lost during their post-Christmas slump. And with their next four games at home, the Knicks (24-14) have an opportunity to keep the momentum rolling.

nytimes_articles.headline: With Issues Unresolved, Police Get Powerful Guns
nytimes_articles.abstract: As 1,000 powerful semiautomatic 9-millimeter handguns are distributed this week for the first time to police officers in precincts throughout New York City, questions about whether the gun is suitable in the city's teeming streets have yet to be resolved.   The distribution is part of the department's yearlong pilot project to determine if the rapid-fire weapons should be issued throughout to the city's 30,000 officers. Some 600 officers in special units have been armed with 9-millimeter handguns for two years in a test, but results of the study are inconclusive, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Rehabbing of America
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE MAKING OF A DRUG-FREE AMERICA    Programs That Work. By Mathea Falco.  254 pp. New York:  Random House/Times Books. $22.   RECKONING   Drugs, the Cities, and the American Future. By Elliott Currie.  405 pp. New York:  Hill & Wang. $25.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Seen on TV
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN a television studio on the West Side, video cameras and monitors surrounded a set that had the look of a chic laboratory, with beakers filled with colored liquid. A 46-year-old woman with her hair in rollers, wearing a baggy black sweater over zebra-striped leggings and no makeup, emerged from the bustling crowd of camera operators and technicians.   "Hello," she said to a visitor. "I'm Georgette Mosbacher."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sasha Lawer, Mark Noonan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alexandra Lawer, the publisher of special publications at the Hearst Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Mark Noonan, a vice president in debt markets at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. The Rev. Steven Geckeler performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.   Ms. Lawer, who is 35 and is known as Sasha, is keeping her name. She graduated from Rutgers University. Her parents are Alexander and Anne Lawer of Oradell, N.J. The bride's father, who is retired, was a pressman for The New York Times. Her mother, also retired, was a secretary at Litton Publications, a medical publisher in Oradell.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From Another Hungarian
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Throughout his life as a physicist, Eugene Wigner, now 90 years old, has sought nature's symmetries. As a result, the physics canon includes Wigner crystals, Wigner theorems, Wigner rules -- all expressions of symmetry and order. THE RECOLLECTIONS OF EUGENE P. WIGNER (Plenum, $24.50), as told to Andrew Szanton, makes it clear that the physicist's love of order has also spilled over into politics. When disorder of the most extreme sort came during World War II, Mr. Wigner's abhorrence of the Nazi plague contributed to a crucial application of physics to warfare: in 1939, he and Leo Szilard drove out to Albert Einstein's summer hideaway on Long Island and persuaded him to write the letter to President Roosevelt that initiated the Manhattan project, the development of a fission weapon. The project itself brought together a brilliant quartet of Hungarian physicists -- Eugene Wigner, Leo Szilard, Edward Teller and John von Neumann -- all of whom, save Szilard, embraced conservative politics after the war. Mr. Wigner became strongly anti-Communist and a supporter of the Vietnam War, largely, he says, because he saw a fearful symmetry between Nazism and Communism. Even Mr. Wigner's discussion of 

l'affaire 

Oppenheimer -- how J. Robert Oppenheimer lost his security clearance after Mr. Teller testified against him -- is marked by a search for balance: he is evenhanded to his close friend Mr. Teller and to the downfallen leader of Los Alamos. Only when it comes to the political intrigues and turf wars in postwar weapons research does Mr. Wigner seem less than fair. On the whole, this memoir avoids the pitfalls of the as-told-to autobiography and serves as a useful addition to the history of science and science policy in the 20th century.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
Aging Gracefully in Granite Springs
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FRITZ'S, in the county for at least two dozen years, first in a fondly remembered luncheonette in Somers and now in a cute, countryesque restaurant in Granite Springs, has moved gracefully into mellow middle age. Eschewing the racy flourishes of its youth, the kitchen has settled into serving with some consistency solid, wholesome fare with enough culinary surprises here and there to amuse the palates of a faithful local clientele. The trick to having a terrific meal here is to zoom in on those surprises.

A staple at Fritz's for so long that they are no longer unusual but are delicious anyway are the freshly baked breads and scones set down on every table, compelling mouthfuls that make waiting for the first course painless. And one of those beguiling appetizers was baked mushrooms, a ubiquitous item so predictable -- seasoned bread crumbs in mushroom caps -- so we thought, that we were tempted to ignore it. But the dish turned out to be smashing. These mushroom caps arrived stuffed with a fine mince of aromatic vegetables and finished with a melt of Monterey Jack cheese, a nip of tarragon and a butter sauce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Case Receives 30-Day Suspension
nytimes_articles.abstract: WALTER CASE JR., the record-setting harness driver, has received a 30-day suspension for failing to take a urine test, a New Jersey state racing commission official said yesterday.   HUGH GALLAGHER, chief steward for standardbred racing for the New Jersey Racing Commission, said he issued the suspension Thursday. But Case appealed and the commission granted a stay.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Department Simplifies Its Overseas Advisories
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS part of its task of safeguarding Americans while they are out of the United States, the State Department has for 15 years been issuing sporadic cautionary reports on conditions in foreign countries, advising citizens not to travel to particular places, to be wary of certain situations, or to be aware of the level of certain crimes against Americans.   These reports, known as travel advisories, went to the news organizations, the travel industry and companies operating abroad, and were available to members of the public by phone and computer. The advisories had a strong influence on travel plans. Abercrombie & Kent said it lost $300,000 in retail bookings for Kenya safaris in 1991 when a warning was issued about Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bevin M. Maguire And Craig P. Hunt
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lieut. Col. Frank J. Maguire of the Army, retired, and Mrs. Maguire of Wilton, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Bevin Mary Maguire and Craig Phillips Hunt, the son of Sarah Hunt of Leesburg, Va., and Roger Hunt of Fountain Hills, Ariz.   Ms. Maguire, 30, is the manager of marketing communications for the Rockefeller Center complex in New York. She graduated from New York University. Her father is the assistant director of veterans' employment and training for New York State, in Manhattan. Her mother, Maureen R. Maguire, retired as a director of special projects at the New York City Board of Education in Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Sports White Paper for Clinton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Having made his initial cabinet and staff appointments and settled into the Oval Office, President Clinton can now get on with the business of governing. Sort of. How he organizes his White House and who he puts in certain non-Cabinet posts will add texture to the broad vision of renewal articulated in his inaugural address.    Presidential sports policy involves far more than calling the locker room of the winning team after the championship game. For example, some of his organizational and hiring decisions can and should reflect commitments to specific policy aims in the area of sports and fitness.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marie W. Blair, Arnold Beermann
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marie W. Blair of Wilson, N.C., and William J. Blair Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marie Watson Blair to Arnold Edward Beermann Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beermann of Douglaston, Queens. A June wedding is planned.   Miss Blair is a customer relations representative at Christie's in New York, the auction house. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her father is the owner and chief executive of the Nordic Group Inc., a refrigerated warehouse and distribution company in Wilmington. Her mother is a writer. The prospective bride is a stepdaughter of Sue Ann Blair of Wilmington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Solace for Victims of Chronic Pain
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR Eileen Arena of Holtsville, the recent holiday was the first time in many years she was able to shop for gifts, because she had finally mustered the courage to ask for help. She suffers from chronic pain, which prevents her from walking any distances or carrying anything heavy.

"It was a big accomplishment for me to ask for help," Ms. Arena said. "I asked the managers in several department stores if they could have someone help me carry my packages. I explained my handicap and that I could not walk through the store carrying things.

nytimes_articles.headline: Croats Battle Serbs for a Key Bridge Near the Adriatic
nytimes_articles.abstract: Croatian forces and Serbs traded artillery and small-arms fire today near Zadar, a port on the Adriatic, a day after the Croats mounted surprise assaults hoping to wrest a vital bridge and airport from the Serbs.   The fighting continued today despite a statement by Croatian officials asserting that a "limited" offensive had been halted.

nytimes_articles.headline: Making a Street: Forget About Logos On the Skyline
nytimes_articles.abstract: Building as object, building as icon: that was the mode corporate architecture favored in the 1980's, when the goal of every company indulging in the act of construction seemed to be to end up with a trademark on the skyline. The most important criterion for judging a building's success as a symbol of corporate aspirations in that extravagant decade was not whether it functioned well, or whether it contributed anything to its surroundings, but whether it looked strikingly different and created an easily identifiable form.    The best proof around that such times are past -- and the best paradigm for urban corporate architecture in the 90's -- is the set of buildings finished late last year for Capital Cities/ABC along West 66th and West 67th Streets on the West Side of Manhattan. This is the utter opposite of architecture as logo. First, it isn't a single structure, standing apart like a prima donna; it is an array of five new buildings and a couple of renovated ones that contains the headquarters and a large chunk of the production facilities for this communications company and its television network. As a complex, the buildings make a statement about the workplace that is good, and a statement about urban architecture that is essential.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hard Landing in Tokyo
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE BUBBLE ECONOMY   Japan's Extraordinary Speculative Boom of the 80's and the Dramatic Bust of the 90's. By Christopher Wood. 210 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

nytimes_articles.headline: County Draws Up A Wish List For Albany
nytimes_articles.abstract: EACH year at this time, lawmakers in the county sit down with experts in the executive branch to draw up a legislative shopping list for Albany -- legislation that Westchester's political leaders believe would reduce costs, increase revenues or simply enhance the quality of life.   The proposals must run a challenging political gantlet in order to be acceptable not only to Democrats and Republicans on the Board of Legislators but also to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and Westchester's Albany delegations in the State Assembly and the State Senate. The Assembly delegation is controlled by Democrats, the Senate delegation by Republicans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds of Venice
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Your essay, "The Serene Sounds of Venice" (Dec. 20), brought to mind our trip there several years ago.   My wife and I went into a square at about 10 o'clock at night, in a residential neighborhood far from the usual tourist areas. The silence was eerie.

nytimes_articles.headline: SETTLING IN: The Media; Outdoing Bush, President Keeps the Press at Bay
nytimes_articles.abstract: On President Clinton's first full day in office, his Administration's communications strategy was already clear: tightly control the information flow to reporters as the President speaks directly to the people.   In a move that even the Reagan Administration never tried for all its sophistication in the ways of the media, Mr. Clinton wore a wireless microphone when he greeted thousands of citizens who strolled through the White House for an open house. While television stations could pick up his warm exchanges with the visitors, reporters were kept behind a rope line several feet away, shouting questions about the hostilities in Iraq and other breaking news. Mr. Clinton refused to acknowledge them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Easing Racial Tensions With a Night of Melody
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RONALD HARRISON, the vice president for community affairs at Pepsico here, was reflecting on the state of race relations in the county. "I don't think we do any worse than other places," said Mr. Harrison, who is black. "But I always thought Westchester should do better, because we are more affluent. There's almost a Mason-Dixon Line between northern and southern Westchester."

Seated at tables in Pepsico's sunny breakfast room were representatives of 14 community organizations, many run by blacks, that serve the county's needy and strive to eliminate ethnic tensions. The groups had been chosen to benefit from Music America, a program sponsored jointly by Pepsico and the New Orchestra of Westchester in celebration of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Black History Month.
